results.question: What are the plans under remuneration measure?
results.markdown_table_response: The following table shows the 2019 remuneration targets and actual values, along with the key performance indicators.
results.csv_string_response:
The group remuneration measures are as follows:
Group operating profit (GOP): the group’s operating profit. This is calculated by subtracting the cost of the items and the cost of capital from revenue, before any taxes are deducted. This is then divided by the number of group members, to produce an annual operating profit figure.
Group cash generation (GCG): the group’s cash generation (i.e. the total amount of cash generated by the group in the year), calculated by adding the group’s cash generation in the previous year to the total cash generation of the group in the current year.
Group ROCE (relative operating return on capital employed): this is the group’s return on capital employed (ROE) compared to the average ROE of the industry. This is calculated by dividing the group’s operating profit (i.e. the group’s operating profit minus the group’s cost of capital) by the average ROE of the industry.
Group remuneration measure: the group’s remuneration measure, calculated by adding the remuneration of the group’s employees to the remuneration of the group’s executive directors and senior managers.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
Basic EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

results.question: What resulted in the increase in the amortization of purchased intangibles included in the CTS operating results?
gold_answer: amortization of purchased intangibles for companies acquired by CTS in fiscal year 2019.
results.markdown_table_response: The increase in the amortization of purchased intangibles included in the CTS operating results was primarily caused by the adoption of ASC 606. ASC 606 requires that a purchase price be amortized over the life of the contract or acquisition, which includes both the contract period and the option period. ASC 606 also requires that an adjustment be made to reflect the fair value of an acquired company's intangible assets on the date of the transaction. In addition, ASC 606 requires that all recognized intangible assets be amortized in the period in which the assets are recognized, including the period in which the assets are acquired. The adoption of ASC 606 resulted in the amortization of purchased intangibles for CTS in fiscal year 2019 of $22.0 million.
results.csv_string_response: The adoption of ASC 606 resulted in an increase in the amortization of purchased intangibles in the CTS operating results. The adoption of ASC 606 also resulted in an increase in the amortization of purchased intangibles for companies acquired by CTS in fiscal year 2019.
results.json_rows_response: In 2019, CTS continued to expand its global operations and continued to acquire companies in the U.S., Europe, and Asia. These acquisitions increased CTS’s domestic operations and enabled it to better serve its existing customers. In addition, CTS continued to invest in new equipment and continue to develop new markets in the U.S. and Europe. For example, in the U.S., CTS acquired the K-1 Handling Services business of BearingPoint in March 2019. CTS also acquired an additional company in the U.S. during fiscal 2019, which is currently under review. In the U.S., CTS acquired a business in the New York City area for approximately $1.5 million.

results.question: Which locations are responsible for driving the increase in sales in 2019?
results.markdown_table_response: As stated in the answer above, sales in 2019 increased 27% to $849.8 million compared to $670.7 million in 2018, which includes the impact of the adoption of ASC 606. The increase in sales was primarily driven by growth in both organic and inorganic business in North America. Sales in 2019 were higher in the U.S. primarily due to system development on contracts in New York, Boston, and the San Francisco Bay Area. Businesses acquired by CTS during fiscal year 2019, whose operations are all located in the U.S., had sales of $74.4 million in fiscal year 2019. Sales increased slightly in Australia between fiscal years 2018 and 2019 as increased system development work on a contract in Brisbane was partially offset by the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates as well as a decrease in service sales. Sales were lower in the UK primarily due to a decrease in system development work in London and the negative impact of currency exchange rates. The average exchange rates between the prevailing currencies in our foreign operations and the U.S. dollar resulted in a decrease in CTS sales of $22.2 million for 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the British pound and Australian dollar.
